summary: In this noir classic, detective Sam Spade (Humphrey Bogart) gets more than he bargained for when he takes a case brought to him by a beautiful but secretive woman (Mary Astor). As soon as Miss Wonderly shows up, trouble follows as Sam's partner is murdered and Sam is accosted by a man (Peter Lorre) demanding he locate a valuable statuette. Sam, entangled in a dangerous web of crime and intrigue, soon realizes he must find the one thing they all seem to want: the bejeweled Maltese falcon.

reviews.content: They don't make movies like this anymore. What a tragedy that is.
One of the best movies I've ever seen. Great mystery with Bogart at his best. All young men should watch how Sam Spade handles himself.

Humphrey Bogart's tough and gritty performance gives The Maltese Falcon the same punch that the movie carried over 80 years ago. It has some pacing issues mid-way through, but remains gripping through important dialogue and memorable one-liners delivered perfectly by a perfect cast.
One of the best Noir films you will ever watch

While true Cinephiles will hold it deer as the origin of many film noir tropes we take advantage of today, The Maltese Falcon is nonetheless too quick-dialogue-heavy to truly sit through and enjoy today.

Its reputation is greater than the sum of its parts.  Plot is obtuse;  Bogie sorts it all out in the finale to make sense of what hasn't been shown to the audience.  My biggest complaint is the casting of Goodie Two Shoes Mary Astor as the femme fatale; she simply isn't good looking enough to be convincing here as a chubby 35 year old. Yeah, she had been boffo box office for quite a while but that was a decade earlier and mostly in lightweight B Movie comedies.  The role called for someone like Lauren Bacall.
Classic noir still watchable and enjoyable. Early example of anti-hero played by Bogart.

"| Ratings Categories |
{Characters (8/10) ; Cinematography (8.5/10) ; Plot (8/10) ; Acting (6.5/10) ; Pacing (8/10) = 78%}"
Shout out to short king Humphrey Bogart, this man was at least 6" shorter than I figured he was. Enjoyed this well enough on his performance alone.

It's incredible to think that The Maltese Falcon, one of the most influential and popular film noirs of all time, was directed by a newbie. John Huston is a big name now, but back then this was his directorial debut. The film has all the elements you'd expect from the genre: hard boiled lead character, male characters wearing what looks to be the same suit and hat, beautiful but transparently untrustworthy women in danger, a story full of twists and turns, dark rooms, low angle shots and a liberal helping of alcohol and cigarettes. Humphrey Bogart cemented his star-status in this role, and his onscreen person would be imitated by countless others. A man with a voice like his was born to play this kind of part. It's got a great supporting cast too, with many big names contributing to the occasionally confusing plot. For me the script was a bit too excessive, and some of the confrontations went on a bit long. It's also distracting that the eponymous falcon apparently weighs so much because it's made of precious metal and its surface is diamond-encrusted, but it's clearly light enough to be handled by the cast members, and not bumpy, as you'd imagine something studded with diamonds to be. In terms of film noir, I definitely prefer Double Indemnity and especially Touch Of Evil, finding their stories and characters more compelling overall, but The Maltese Falcon is a cinematic classic for a reason, and one I very much enjoyed watching.

Just a terrific film. The plot and the pacing is perfect, it's funny without being silly, it's exciting and poignant, and the film is shot beautifully. Mary Astor gets her character exactly right, and Peter Lorre and Sydney Greenstreet are great too. Humphrey Bogart is playing pretty much the same character here and in Casablanca, and both are wonderful-- the outward cynicism and the ambiguity about the characters' true integrity is so fun to watch.
Film noir at its finest. Bogart is a classic and paired with bacall...it doesn't get any better.

Sam Spade's immortal statement alluding to "the stuff that dreams are made of" may as well have been self-referential, as this absorbing, monumental work proves in every sense that it is the granddaddy of the noir genre. With one swoop, director John Huston sets the stage with all of the iconic trademarks of smokey, dark-alleyway detective stories to come. Hard-boiled cynicism, fallible protagonists, blood-curdling avarice, and labyrinthine plot developments pave the way for an infinitely absorbing and ultimately unforgettable work about the persistence of delusion and the negotiable price of human loyalty. The film's gritty aesthetic washes over you as the web-like story grips you in its sticky tendrils, all the while leaving the unmistakable impression that you are witnessing something truly historic. If watching for the first time, be prepared to watch all over again once it is over.

Peter Lorre, is just hysterically amusing , Great,, the faces wow

and this movie and Casablanca, just make Humpfrey  Bogart,   the guy ,, wow
Noir, Bogart and Huston all at their finest!
Legendary and unforgettable, The Maltese Falcon remains one of cinema's most delightful features today.
The Sharp and smooth The Maltese Falcon shines thanks to the sensibilities of it's leads.
I can't relate to any of the characters. The story is dull. Couldn't finish it.

Faithfully adapted from the Dashiell Hammett novel, John Huston's The Maltese Falcon is an entertaining film noir romp, despite being a bit dated.  The complex plot involves various factions seeking a rare and expensive statuette, including Humphrey Bogart as the tough-talking and face- slapping Sam Spade, Peter Lorre as the sniveling henchman Joel Cairo, and Sydney Greenstreet as Kasper "Fat Man" Gutman, the dangerous but always reasonable antagonist.  The acting is a bit over the top at times, the continuity is inconsistent, and the story may require a second viewing to fully understand the complex plot, but watching it is undeniably a good time.
Enjoyable from start to finish

The Maltese falcon is pure real noir at its very finest, and to this very day is still one of the best films of all time., along with director John Huston's directorial debut makes it even more impressive. Humphrey Bogart is fantastic with his one liners and exquisite acting. The only negative I would have here is that the story does get a little convoluted and muddied at times but the acting from Bogart and Astor save the film.

I know it's considered a classic and on the "movie must-watch list", but it doesn't hold up well...if it ever was any good in the first place.  The characters are unlikable and the actors speak ontop of each other saying their memorized lines too quickly as if they just want to get through the performance. Mary Astor is pretentious and overdramatic while Boggie comes across as a caricature. There is a very weak plot and little suspense or action in this film noir.  The characters just shuffle back and forth between the PI's office, a hotel, and the PI's home. Everyone is lying, threatening, and bribing each other while trying to gain possession of an expensive statue of a falcon. The film is a mess! There are many plot holes and ludicrous scenes of characters pulling guns and childishly smacking each other. It's actually laughable at times.  To make matters worse, the two leads have no chemistry and there is no character development which makes the love story a complete joke. Honestly, except for getting to cross this off my movie bucket list, it's barely worth the time IMHO!  (I read that the 1931 original is much better)

The Maltese Falcon is a unique piece of movie history. I love the performances of Humphrey Bogart, Mary Astor, Sydney Greenstreet and Peter Lorre. I also enjoy the direction, writing and set designs. Overall, The Maltese Falcon is one of the best movies ever made.

Possibly the most over-rated movie ever? It has not aged well. Sure, influential, peak noir, showcasing Bogart etc. etc. My complaint is not that it’s boring or that the dialogue is too fast or that it’s confusing. It is simply absurd - characters fall love after three sentences of dialogue, minor characters are barely developed so you know they’re there just to be killed off, and the plot isn’t just convoluted - I don’t mind that - it’s absurdly, childishly, arbitrarily convoluted, as though the director or screenwriter just thought of plot twists while filming to stretch it out a bit more - and worse, the twists were predictable as well as absurd. There’s better out there.

This one took two times to watch in order to wrap my brain around. Fast dialogue and frame movement. Humphrey plays a hardened, angry, and compelling detective to solve the murder of his business partner. Great acting on all parts with several twists.

Two houndred years after its release (well, at least it feels this way...) "Maltese Falcon" is maybe not as gripping and electrifying as I imagine it was in 1820, when it was first shown on a big screen, but at least the climate is still there, and it is as dense and heavy as always. Humphrey Bogart with his dry delivery and cleverly written lines shines without a doubt while Mary Astor failed to captivate me as she captivated our protagonist. But the main problem with this movie was for me its plot – namely how linear and unsurprising it was. I certainly expected something more complicated from the father of all McGuffin-based movies – at least one switcharoo to spice things up a bit and more mystery than plain exposition. But maybe I expected a tad too much. After all, it has been two houndred years...

Classic film-Noir. A good cast. Humphrey Bogart as a hard boiled detective. Some great one liners. The cast is fairly good. 

It's a must watch for film noir lovers. 


"What is this?" 

"The stuff that dreams are made of."

AFI 100 Greatest Films - #23: Having read the Hammett novel just a few weeks ago the first thing I noticed was how faithful John Huston remained to the source material, even taking whole lines of dialogue from the page verbatim. This move proved just as well sighted as the casting, and I am not sure if the resulting scripts tightness was due more to this being Huston's first big directing job or his recognition of Hammett's genius when it comes to the genre. The fast talking tough guy with a heart which Bogart embodies comes off near perfectly as Sam Spade while Greenstreet, Astor and Lorre offer excellent supporting work. The plot Hammett cooked up is such an entertaining and dizzying little mystery that, and thankfully Mr. Huston agreed, doesn't require much artistic license from anyone else.

Honestly, what is all the fuss about? Everyone treats this movie like the Messiah, it has topped the AFI and critics lists, yet i have not seen it in a list with the most effective insomnia treatments. I understand that it has contributed to the noir genre and has solid acting, especially Bogart, but that doesn't justify its boring, overly sophisticated screenplay, boring dialogue and stupid side characters. It starts promisingly enough, with Bogart's friend being murdered by someone. Then, Peter Lorre is introduced and the movie goes downhill. Even the most uneducated random person on the street talks like an academic with a Masters in English, the fat villain is extremely clumsily developed to the point where he becomes a clown and the tense, violent moments are non descript. The Falcon itself looks like a sculpted turd and the Femme Fatale is everything but interesting. The pacing is slow like a snail and literally nothing works.
Don't watch it if you get bored easily. 
The stuff dreams are made of are Huston's horribly slow pacing and complicated screenplay.
While not as good as Chinatown, this is probably the second best noir of all time, with devious characters, lots of suspense, a good mystery, and a bittersweet ending.

Bogart's voice is so annoying. Unsure how this can be regarded as a classic, it's a simple but boring mystery and plays out increasingly unrealistically. Nothing exciting to the film but I like that Peter Lorre showed up with his cracking villain accent. Generally it's a film I'll forget rapidly.
I got lost while watching it and I most certainly will be watching it again as soon as possible to understand it. I think that The Maltese Falcon benefits off of its intriguing and mysterious nature.
I hate Bogart and this is still an amazing film with a great supporting cast.

There's a reason Humphrey Bogart and John Huston, in his first shot at directing, were proving they were the best at what they do. Huston was a craftsman, bringing out the most entertaining story possible. It had suspense, intrigue, drama, humor. It had a good plot.
Not a great plot. It's not easy to follow, but you learn with these things aren't designed to make sense. You're not really supposed to be one step ahead of the detective.
But you eventually catch up
John Huston is on that short list of directors whose first effort resulted in an iconic film. If you're a movie lover this is one you must watch because it's the stuff that dreams a made of.
Bogart, Huston, Noir. Art.
While the book is one of the finest detective stories ever written, the movie is even better.  And this was the first appearance of Sidney Greenstreet on film.

I gotta be honest, this movie is seen as a masterpiece and innovator of film noir and I definitely recognize and respect that, but personally I don't think that the film has aged as well for consumption of general audiences today. The whole time I was watching this, I felt like I was waiting for a big and thrilling suspenseful scene that ended up never coming. The acting is superb I just think that the general plot needed some more "pep" so to speak. Maybe I just need to let this film marinate with me a little longer. I really wanted to love this movie and I was disappointed that I didn't when the screen when black.

Everybody needs their black and white cherry popped and this was mine. Sure I'd seen some other monochrome flicks before this as a youth working my way through popcorn flicks and cartoons and disney back catalogues and the birth of CGI like most youngsters in the early to mid 90's. And those black and white films I watched at school and college were tinny with flat frames, austere music and silly, boring, cheesy dialogue. But as soon as I finished The Maltese Falcon, a film I found on my own, working my way backwards through hardboiled and detective fiction and films I was interested in, it had blown my mind.

Quintessential early film noir; it's a stage play locked into some beautiful environments with some electric characters that pop up, chew scenery, rock Sam Spade's world and then wait in the wings until called upon again. The easy, watchable charm of The Maltese Falcon always has me coming back. It's not a particularly involving film, nor is the mystery very satisfying, but instead it's just a very easy film to follow, and an easy film to watch. It's not got too much of the pep of later film noirs, it's not as cheeky, but it is classy. It's a non-politicised, non-romantic Casablanca. It's boiled hard and beautiful, biting and subtle. There's as much not-said between the dialogue as there is said, Bogart's tiny, hard, jewelled dead eyes that still manage to sparkle.

San Francisco has a refreshing feel; the more manicured and professional stiffness of Sam Spade and his world is a companion piece to the cheap comedy and acerbic empty wit that Philip Marlow and his Los Angeles brings in some of those equally popular film noirs.

Also, considering that it's allegedly a verbatim copy of the source novel, there's nuance and vibrancy in every scene and every moment. As someone who never found Hammet's novels as interesting reads, the film zips along and never explains anything until it has to.

One of the greatest if film classics. One of Bogart's best performances, one of Huston's best as director. By far the best of the three Maltese Falcon movies (including Satan Met A Lady) and very very accurate to the Dashiell Hammett novel. Gets better with every viewing.

The story is most artfully told with great dialogue delivered by a great cast. The only thing that bothers me is Mary Astor as the femme fatale. She never convinced me with her performance or appearance. Bette Davis would have been perfect .

A very overrated film. The best thing about The Maltese Falcon is the atmosphere in it, the ambience; the dialogue itself is often ridiculous (it's no wonder this has been parodied in joke form for so many years) and the story is convoluted as hell, with the 100 mph dialogue only making it more difficult to understand at times.
There are far worse movies, though this semi-incomprehensible movie being rated so extremely highly is just ridiculous. It's not Bogart at his best by any means - see The Treasure Of The Sierra Madre for that.
There are worse films, but this ain't a great one, just interesting. Again, more mood than actually a great story; it gets by from its reputation and its "coolness." It's all a pose...and if you can take it as that, you may enjoy it more than I did.
A film that is Action packed and fun.
Great movie Bogart is perfect.

This could be a 2 set play.
Bros and does jockey for treasure.

Often referred to as the first real film noir this film launched Humphrey Bogart to superstardom and served as the directorial debut of the legendary John Huston who would go on to produce other masterpieces like The Dead (1987) and Fat City (1972). There is so much to appreciate in the film as it really does set out all of the iconic tropes that would become staples of the noir genre and yet it is a weird little film for one that is so often quoted as I could not name another film that is quite like it. It hasn't aged a day in 78 years and is still an entertainingly dark tale of a group of sad, desperate people.

Private investigator Sam Spade, Humphrey Bogart, works with Miles Archer, Jerome Cowan, but is having an affair with his wife Iva, Gladys George. The two are employed by the mysterious Ruth Wonderly, Mary Astor, who asks them to tail Floyd Thursby, a man she claims is threatening her sister. The two men do not believe her story but take on the job anyway leading to Archer being murdered by an unknown killer. Spade becomes a primary suspect due to his affair with Archer's wife and when he discovers that Thursby was also killed the night of the murder he realizes he is part of a larger conspiracy. Wonderly provides him with some help when she reveals that she is actually Brigid O'Shaughnessy and was in cahoots with Thursby and he later connects her to the imposing Joe Cairo, Peter Lorre, who is looking for the Maltese Falcon. Cairo is employed by Kasper Gutman, Sydney Greenstreet, whom Spade was already familiar with and when the dying captain of a ship drops off the Maltese Falcon in Spade's office. Sadly this item is not the real thing and this creates more conflict between the members of the motley crew that have assembled.

Bogart was the big surprise for me here as I was not entirely sold on him from his work in Casablanca (1943), a film I find to be highly overrated, and his overstated work in The Desperate Hours (1955). I found him refreshing here as while he has a reputation for being dark and brooding he played Spade as a character who is wounded, damaged and laconic, prerequisites for a detective in a film noir, but also as a man with a sense of humor and self awareness. He knows that it is unwise getting taken in by the charms of Astor and when she spouts off her tall tales he is able to chuckle at how silly it all is. He is helped by a fantastic screenplay of course as this film forces him to really build a character instead of relying on the Bogart-isms that later roles would require of him. He seems to exist outside of space and time as he is a man who always seems to have been old and weathered despite this being relatively early in Bogart's career and his mannerisms and gestures are still replicated by men today.

The film also uses it's tropes to great effect and even subverts a few as the femme fatale in this film is presented differently than many future versions would. Astor seems like an unlikely casting choice as she doesn't have the glamour of Ava Gardner in The Killers (1946) or Rita Hayworth in Gilda (1946). Yet this plays into her hands as she is able to sell herself as a vulnerable, self destructive woman to a man who does not know what he wants or needs. We feel incredibly nervous towards the end of the film as we worry that our lead's love for this woman will outweigh his devotion to his job and I have rarely been so gripped at the end of the film. This is a tribute to the way that the character is written as she avoids most clichés to become a unique cinematic achievement that etches herself permanently in the minds of viewers.

The gorgeous cinematography of Arthur Edeson also deserves mention as he practically defines the visual style that would dominate the genre with plenty of light streaming through windows and characters surrounded by darkness. It is fortunate that Huston assembled such great talent as he brings them together for a film worthy of their talents.

This was mine and my father's greatest movie of all time. It was a little more understanding then The Big Sleep and a little more rough than To Have and to Have Not.  While I  Recommend all of the aforementioned movies, I think the Falcon will give you the most joy.This movie is fantastic...... just give it a watch

A great mystery movie and melodrama, but not quite as good as I remember, primarily because neither the love story between Humphrey Bogart and Mary Astor, nor Astor's performance in the first half of the film, were so believable.  Among all the other things in the film which do work, and brilliantly, special praise should go to the screenplay.  The way that the characters refer to each other and suspect each other creates layers of intricacy that deepen the mystery and lock us into every word and every scene.
Outstanding film, loved the black and white!!!

Last night I had the awesome experience of being able to go to the cinema and watch John Huston's The Maltese Falcon for the first time as part of the Flashback Cinema with my awesome wife (she agreed to go with me even though she isn't a film buff like me). It was one of the best experiences I've had in a theater. We arrived early and we were the only patrons in the theater until a few minutes before the start of the film. The 6 other people who arrived were very quiet and respectful during the whole thing. The movie was amazing! The acting, dialogue, and direction was awesome! It was interesting to watch a film from 1941 (53 years before I was born) at the movie theater. The aspect ratio being 1.37:1 was especially cool to see in such a blown up screen. I will definitely be purchasing the Blu-Ray soon and re-watching it. Even my wife enjoyed it. I would highly recommend watching this if you haven't before. I am a fan of some older black and white movies, but now I really want to dive deep!This is the stuff dreams are made of!

We enjoyed this classic movie very much. I've seen this movie many times, but there were several instances where I noticed something new I never saw before. Some of the actor's facial expressions and emotions were better seen on the big screen.

Classic cinema at its finest. Loses a star due to aging poorly (scenes like Sam forcing a woman to pay for his services via sexual favors). There are also some parts where even Humphrey Bogart appears to be laughing at how ridiculous the situation is. The directing is still top-notch from the lighting, to the camera angles, to the line delivery.
Of all the films made in all the towns, in all the world, its (luckily) shown in mine.  Very entertaining
I'm not quite sure it is the greatest film of all time, but The Maltese Falcon is a fine early film noir. Bogart particularly is spellbinding and the script is a joy.

Bogart is bluffing with such authenticity, he is deep and cannot be disenchanted; enters a lady with a tricky case.

The Maltese Falcon

Huston is, as a storyteller, simply narrating. A lot of directors have come and gone, but none of them was just reading it to you, tucking you in, he whispers the book in his infamous adaptation like it is his, the director's, John Huston. The story, if you are aware of it, has been wielded before too, but it didn't come out this durable and.. well, shiny. The narration is a bit tricky in here, since it is something that would- I wanna say be better if on paper, because it is and it was good- resist if exaggerated.

The scenarios, the characters, the entire tone of this film-noir is bound within four walls. It ping-pongs here are there with "He said. She said" affair where as an audience you are in a rush to figure out what actually is going on or has been going on in this first act. After which the film reveals all its cards and we relaxed back in our seats, hoping for something "Bang!" to go wrong. But it doesn't. This is where the film cheated me the most and left me in awe of it.

For if I think about it I never wanted it to go wrong or right or in fact anywhere. Huston's filmmaking is so present in that room where around three to four major characters are sitting around or roaming about that you don't want this day to end. Anticipation is the game then, and the tease, is Huston's key to success. Watch how a simple phone call or a knock on the door pumps up your heartbeat fast, scared, hoping that it wouldn't collapse, "The stuff that dreams are made of." The Maltese Falcon is as good as any historic event, I say claim it history and be done with it.

This film left me feeling confused and inadequate. I love movies, always have, and consider myself a fairly good judge of taste and quality. This all time classic had been on my list of films to watch for many years and after finally watching it I'm doubting myself as a human being. Is there something really wrong with me and my sensibilities? Am I completely disillusioned about my knowledge and understanding of movies? I don't know how such a beloved film by apparently anyone who knows anything about films could leave me in such dismay. I was baffled how this could be regarded so highly. I obviously have missed something and I'm not quite sure what that could be other than nostalgia perhaps. Help! Is there something wrong with me? I swear I love movies! Always have and always will. How could I absolutely love The Treasure of the Sierra Madre, another Humphrey Bogart and John Houston film, and have this one go completely over my head? Maybe I need to learn to listen and pay attention better, but I really did give it my undivided attention. Maybe I'm just out of touch and not as much of a connoisseur as I thought myself to be. Man, this one is really messing me up.

A film noir with no sentimentalism.

John Huston's The Maltese Falcon (1941) is a classic example of film noir with overly sentimental attitude. Characters are blunt liars and selfish scum. There are few decent people in The Maltese Falcon as everyone is out for theirs. Huston's script is full of clever wit, dry humor, and cruel betrayal.

Huston's direction is clean, dark, ambient film noir at its finest. Many of the shots with Humphrey Bogart are as dark and revealing as cinema gets. The way Huston lets a shot still to engage the audience with his characters is impressive, especially as the editing is quick and the film goes by quickly. The Maltese Falcon's hour and a half running time feels like a half hour. It's brisk storytelling is amplified by its complex narrative and endless twists. I will not spoil any of the genuinely surprising moments.

Humphrey Bogart is a great star and a formidable actor. His monologues and rage sear the screen with his ferocious acting. Bogart's performance as Sam Spade in The Maltese Falcon ranges from nuanced detective with a sly and knowing manner to a fierce tempered brash man of action. He is interesting and captivating without having to be likable at all really. Bogart's noir detective is one for the ages!

Mary Astor may overdo it a bit, but she captures the nebulous ways of a woman in distress looking out for herself. Her endless string of lies is so entertaining as Bogart uncovers them one by one, while never quite figuring her out. Astor is certainly intriguing and alluring as Brigid O'Shaughnessy.

Peter Lorre is hilarious and funny as the sleazy and creepy Joel Cairo. You will never forget his charming and quirky Cairo character. Lorre is both convincing as his strange characters, while also entertaining you with his mystery and commitment.

Likewise, Sydney Greenstreet's massive character Kasper "Fat Man" Gutman is excellent. His fascinating monologue over the history of The Maltese Falcon is riveting. He evens summarizes the plot towards the end with an underhanded sneer and distinct delight in his voice.

Overall, Huston's film noir The Maltese Falcon is an entertaining movie with many great attributes. It's not completely mesmerizing or so perfect in performances that everyone is a star. But, The Maltese Falcon is great for a watch and a display of complicated writing.

One of the quintessential much watch 'Film Noirs'.   Into the offices of the Spade & Archer detective agency sweeps a Miss Wonderly (Mary Astor), who offers a large retainer to Sam and his partner Miles Archer (Jerome Cowan) if they'll protect her from someone named Floyd Thursby. The detectives believe neither Miss Wonderly nor her story, but they believe her money. Since Archer saw her first, he takes the case -- and later that evening he is shot to death, as is the mysterious Thursby. Miss Wonderly's real name turns out to be Brigid O'Shaughnessey, and, as the story continues, Sam is also introduced to the effeminate Joel Cairo (Peter Lorre) and the fat, erudite Kasper Gutman (Sydney Greenstreet, in his film debut). It turns out that Brigid, Cairo and Gutman are all international scoundrels, all involved in the search for a foot-high, jewel-encrusted statuette in the shape of a falcon. 

This is one of the best examples of actionful and suspenseful melodramatic story telling in cinematic form. There's two competing frames of reference throughout: the narrative itself, then a meta-narrative with the characters continually voicing the etiquette of their genre scenario . Arguably the best detective movie ever made in Hollywood.
Hypnotic - best noir of all.
A good Movie if you keep in mind how old it is and a real classic
A film noir masterpiece starring Humphrey Bogart, Peter Lorre, Sydney Greenstreet and Mary Astor. The Maltese Falcon made Humphrey Bogart  famous and even saved Lorre's carrer. Great film noir.
Great dialogue. Great plot. Great acting. As good as film noir gets

Written and directed by John Huston adapted from a book written by  Dashiell Hammett starring movie icon Humphrey Bogart as Private eye detective Sam Spade attempting to solve the murder of his Private eye detective partner, Miles Archer (Jerome Cowan)  accepting what is supposed to be a routine job following someone for a compulsive liar.  The client and manipulator Brigid O'Shaughnessy (Mary Astor) sought along with dealers of Kasper Gutman (Sydney Greenstreet) and Joel Cairo (Peter Lorre) for the infamous "Maltese Falcon" hence the title.
This film was solid.

A brilliant cat mixed with a great director and a suspenseful story makes the Maltese falcon a great noir. It has many great character making the story very enjoyable. Maltese falcon is a great noir story.
A movie well-deserving of it's reputation as a classic
Thrilling, superbly written and stupendously acted by the whole cast, the Maltese Falcon has endured as one of cinema's timeless classics.
Finally a decent John Huston/Humphrey Bogart vehicle. Huston's directorial debut might be his best.
Well-written and acted, especially from Humphrey Bogart, The Maltese Falcon is a deserved Film-Noir classic that has influenced many of the genre's later great movies.
In My 30 Best Movies Of All Time A Classic
Classic noir in every way.

Some films are perfect. Case in point, The Maltese Falcon, which is probably why a remake of this classic has never been attempted (and probably shouldn't ever be). John Huston admittedly considered Hammett's book a perfect screenplay and that dedication to excellent source material is evident. As stiff as stilted as the acting in many early films can be, the characters in The Maltese Falcon (with only a couple minor exceptions from bit players) seem like real people. Getting close to 80 years from its release Bogart and Astor, supported by Lorre and Greenstreet, continue to thrill.
An immortal masterpiece which created its own legacy.

So much to admire about this film, the depth of the characters and how they are shown "warts and all", the use of shadows to set the tone and it is still a good story! Humphrey Bogart has the cynical Sam Spade cut to perfection and Mary Astor gives a wonderfully nuanced performance as the Femme Fatale.

Although the general mystery is not very difficult to solve (particularly since it is made clear what all the fuss is about the moment the film opens) making it a tad bit predictable, it still manages to be a suspenseful, atmospheric and fantastically cast affair as you, as well as the protagonist, try to figure out how all the players fit together and what their individual angles are. Indeed, it is Bogart's Spade that really makes things interesting as you watch his thoughts and actions, often winging it, as he connects the dots. Along with the well-written and memorable dialogue, you can see exactly how this is one of the most iconic and influential hard-boiled detective stories of all time.

Might have been one of the best films of its time, but with its nonsensical plot leaping from one absurdity to another, and grating background music, it is more a film for historians to note rather than one to actually watch. The "love" relationship that simmers between Bogart and Astor is particulary lame as it does not fit their characters at all. It almost seems like it was tacked on to the screenplay at the last minute to conform with the studio's mandatory checklist. Unless you're a historical film buff just don't bother with this one.

This mystery film noir moves at a fast pace and features a clever screenplay providing both tension and humour between the characters. Bogart is very convincing in his role, but I wasn't so sure about the casting of Astor. Although the plot/dialogue is sometimes a little hard to follow, this is a thoroughly enjoyable and entertaining mystery thriller. Considered to be one of the best movies of all time, and one of the top 10 mystery movies of all time. AAN 1001
This was one outstanding film, it had a great performance for a great lead character, and a story that twists and turns throughout the whole film.

"The stuff that dreams are made of". Yes, not only does 'The Maltese Falcon' is an extremely solid, relentlessly constructed film noir, it is also remarkably intelligent, transcending all requirements demanded for a fine film. Successfully mysterious, it is a tight film whose fast rhythm, undisputed set-pieces and great cast are widely sufficient to please even those who are skeptical to labyrinthine films.

The old studio system produced a classic & launched what became known as film noir. Bogart is his Bogey'iest here, his BS detector smoking-out the femme fatale - yet to meet Bacall. Interesting that this story had been filmed twice before with little success, then boom ...  The 2nd remake actually is pretty good and a bit sexier.
"The things dreams are made of..."
Film Noir with pretty cool one liners, The Maltese Falcon boasts a great performance from Humphrey Bogart and gives a compelling story altogether

a very good movie. plot is believable and holds true to the book. some lines are word for word and several places mentioned can actually be found in San 
Francisco

Paint It Black

The first and best noir film made by the first and best noir writer, Dashiell Hammett. It was also John Huston's first as director and Bogart's breakthrough. It is talky, claustrophobic and perfectly cast as played.

What lifts it above others is the sheer originality and moral complexity of the tale. This is an attack on crass materialism and human depravity that has no peers. All of the characters - except Spade occasionally- are lying all the time, in pursuit of money, sex and power. The Black Bird is itself the great existential bluff, a non-existent cause for action, that symbolises the naked aggression and powerful greed. Spade is the first true anti-hero, uninterested in fame or money, a man possessed by the need to revenge his partner using any means possible.  Like all Hammett leading men, he has his own moral code, one that requires him to spit in the face of authority and get his way no matter what.

This is the first film I watched as a child, and decided, this is beyond me, this is an adult world I don't understand. It still has the power to shock. The femme fatale lies all the time, uses men and packs a gun. The cops are dumb bullies. The DA threatens Spade in a blatant abuse of power. The crooks are gay, ruthless and cultured. The gunman who does most of the killing is the young boyfriend of the lead villain, the Fat Man. 

It really is the 'stuff that dreams are made of - sharp as a tack today as it was in 1941.

This was boring. Nothing exciting happened in the whole movie and the cinematography was basic and devoid of anything of note. Humphrey Bogart's performance was the only think that kept me engaged in the film at all.
I don't get the huge hoopla around this film. The movie was just okay to me. I guess I'm just not a fan of film noir films. I did appreciate the brevity of the film.
"The stuff that dreams are made of."
I had trouble following this movie. I need to learn to listen better.
The Maltese Falcon has a confusing screenplay at times, but the protagonists ability to think ahead twelve steps is the best part of the film.
A cornerstone to film Noir

Noir masterpiece and the stunning debut of John Huston. This movie is one of those rare occasions when a film version doesn't look inferior to the literary source. Everything is perfect in this early and definitive noir, including an awesome adaptation and first rate performances from the entire cast.
Bogie at his best.  Charismatic and badass.  This is the one that pretty much birthed the noir.  And it's still so fantastic.

Honestly I'd prefer a movie about the Millennium Falcon over this. Not to say this was horrible, but old school crime noir movies kinda bore me, no matter who's starring. At least it wasn't over two hours, so there's that.
The Maltese Falcon is one well-made mystery, layered with brilliant details and Humphrey Bogart's great performance, all in for a perfectly timed reveal that still made the film iconic to this day.

The fist fights and emotional females are a bit over the top in this classic crime film, but that is what Hollywood was putting out back then. Bogart is great and the storyline pace is quite snappy for a 1941 film.

I enjoy antiheroes who have to take a whole movie to do anything remotely moral - that's Sam Spade, played as cool and tough as Humphry Bogart knows how.  His sly bravado, tough with police and women, seemingly careless attitude with the death of his partner Archer, make him a questionable character throughout.  He has various affairs, including Archer's wife, which we learn after the poor bastard's been shot.  I more than half expect Spade will end up just as corrupt as the adversaries he is forced to help, and I'm not far off.  His last act is just, but he does it cruel; he's not out to win the audiences heart, just his own.  It's the best way he can make up for his apathy towards Archer.  They cut through the Hollywood cliches with him, and the end kiss is far from romantic or resolving, rather just a tease for what won't be.  That's the kind of character I like to see, but I suppose too often would water it down.  Good to have these types rare.

But the key to making this whole picture work is the trickster, Brigid O'Shaugnessy, who goes by other names to start.  She is a compulsive liar, her ultimate goal never quite clear, nor her feelings, which she may have none besides greed and/or fear.  She always keeps us guessing.  And once we feel settled into one version of the truth, it changes - that happens all through the show, right till the very end.  And if that doesn't captivate, nothing will, because it's the essence of the film's mystery.

Peter Lorre is wildly entertaining, somewhat comic relief, by far the best of the antagonist bunch, if you exclude O'Shaugnessy for being in between.  He plays Cairo, a not-so-tough baddie for the Fat Man on the hunt for Maltese Falcon.  He tends to get his ass kicked by Spade.  As does Fat Man's right hand "like a son" Wilmer, played wonderfully by Elisha Cook Jr, using the same pastiche that make most his other roles work in context; his psycho lemur stare, supersensitivity, frustration, and dumbness.

I am not familiar enough with Huston to weigh his work as a director, but I like his staging, the body language he gets from his actors.  But in conjunction with camera?  Not so much here, which is part of my lacking 5 stars.  I didn't love the cinematography, and noirs are typically an easy sell for me.  I didn't think the photography grabbed me at any particular moment.  The attitudes of the actors did that.  

What the actors didn't convince me of was the violence, which at some points was strong, and others just plain awkward, as are most movies of this time.  Not Cagney, he can hit - but these folks had some strange moves, including the neck hit and straight jacket manuever on Wilmer.  The latter straight jacked move I liked, funny and interesting, but Spade has a bad habit of handing guns back; he does it with Cairo and Cook.  It's a statement of his confidence; he needn't worry about another carrying a gun, and later in the film tells us that it's a talent of his to snatch them - I guess he does it for sport, he enjoys the thrill.  And so does the audience.

I've always known one part of this film, the end line when Spade answers the police about what Maltese Falcon, a fake, is: "it's the stuff that dreams are made of."  Whenever I saw that in a greatest movies highlight reel, it moved me.  In the film itself it confused me, felt contrived, moment-grabbing.  I'm sure there's various explanations, and it's simple enough, but maybe a bit too heavy.  More like it's the thing nightmares are made of, since that's what this journey, and all the people hurt along the way, has been.

Quite good old school detective mystery drama. Humphrey Bogart is a San Francisco private eye. Mary Astor hire him to find a man who can lead to her sister unknown whereabouts. Humphrey partner Jerome Cowan takes her case and is shot dead mysteriously. Mary also gone missing after that. The person which Mary want them to find is also dead. Peter Lorre visit Humphrey and want him to help find this prize treasure falcon. Mary returns and Humphrey keep her presence a secret from the cops. She get nervous when Humphrey mention about Peter and she want to meet him. They talk and mentioned of a fat man. Sydney Greenstreet is the fat man and he also want to make a deal with Humphrey to find the falcon. Although up to this point he don't know where and what is it. Sydney track it for 17 years and finally send 3 agents to steal it from a Russian general. But one of the man know of its value and decide to keep it. Humphrey was drug unconscious. Back at his office, a boat captain came with the falcon and dies. Humphrey decide to set up the meeting. He manage to convince Sydney to make his young henchman Elisha Cook Jr who has been tailing him around, the fall guy for the murders. When Humphrey send for the falcon, it turns out a fake product. Sydney and Peter decide to continue the hunt for the falcon and want back the payment made to Humphrey. Meanwhile Elisha escaped. Humphrey call the cops to catch the duo and further interrogate Mary true purpose. Turns out on that fateful night, the dead agent remain loyal to Mary even after Sydney tries to reason him. Elisha then shot him dead. Mary seduce the captain to keep the falcon and deliver to Humphrey. For Mary's part, she want to get the dead agent out of the story to get the falcon for herself. Jerome is needed to scare him but he didn't appear, so she kill Jerome and pin the crime on the dead agent. But he too is dead, she know Sydney is in town and return to Humphrey for protection. The cops came and he hand Mary over as killer of Jerome.

Not because of all the hype over time, this is a gem, right from the start.  They don't make um like this anymore.
If you have never seen it, watch.

Hollywood remake with one of Humphrey Bogart's finest and most assured performances.  The iconic image and persona of a private detective remains as strong today as it was in the 40's and arguably much of that is down to this film.

Tough and gritty, the film noir classic The Maltese Falcon from 1941 has a fantastic cast, led by Humphrey Bogart in the role of hardboiled detective Sam Spade.   A dame played by, whoops, a woman played by Mary Astor shows up in his office looking for a guy, but for reasons she's not being truthful about.   A couple of murders later, Bogart comes to understand she and others are searching for a priceless antique, a statue of a falcon (from Malta, naturally).   Bogart must navigate the waters between the police, who suspect him, the various tough guys, one of whom is the fantastic Peter Lorrie, and Mary Astor's character, who he's attracted to, but knows he cannot trust.   Along the way, he'll blow smoke in a guy's face, take and give punches, and deliver several good lines, my favorites of which were "When I slap you, you'll take it and like it", and of course, the last one, in response to being asked what the falcon statue was, saying it's "the stuff dreams are made of".  It's regarded as a classic, but for me it's good-not-great.   I think one of the issues is the connection to Astor, I didn't see any real chemistry between the two of them, rendering a couple of the scenes false.  It's certainly worth watching though.
One of the best movies ever made, with one of the best actors to do it (Bogie) ,& a great cast ,I so love this movie

9 out of 10:

Intense, well acted, and sometimes funny, The Maltese Falcon is a recommendation for fans of detective movies, even if it's kind of slow.
The Stuff That Dreams Are Made Of.
What's this movie? "It's the stuff dreams are made of."
Classic and exhibiting the talents of Humphrey Bogart well, Maltese Falcon is filed under quintessential Old Hollywood even if I personally feel it is overhyped.

Watching this in a movie theater makes all the difference. I saw it in Seattle in the 70s on the big screen with a bunch of Bogie fans. It was a fabulous experience. Have seen it several times since on VCR / DVD and still love it but that first time was unforgettable. See it in a theater if you can; if not get a bunch of friends together and make a movie night of it.

The Maltese Falcon takes claim as one of the first film noirs that changed cop movies. Spade gets wrapped up in a quest to find the falcon and used his skills as a P.I. to get the (fake) statue and then bust the crooks he's been invoked with.

The Maltese Falcon is the standard for film noir. From the lighting to the dialogue to the acting, this film is iconic. It's difficult to separate Humphrey Bogart from the cool and collected character of Sam Spade. I wasn't as enamored with Mary Astor as the movie wanted me to be, but the rest of the cast is solid. There's a reason this movie is a classic.
Brilliant film, perfect despite the slightly out dated acting styles.

A fine piece of excellently acted cinema, and the best film noir I've seen so far ! It wans't very easy to understand the whole movie, but it doesn't matter, cause it's good, lovely looking black and white, suspensful and just engenius. And Humphrey Bogart is a major reason to see this movie. Recommended !!
A masterpiece in every way.

Superb film noir with great acting and very tense scenes.

Humphrey Bogart, as usual, is great in his role, as a private detective caught in the middle of a treasure hunt with several thieves. The Maltese Falcon is a very suspenseful film, and one of the most acclaimed of its genre, and it is not hard to understand why. This 100 minutes film has everything you could expect from a noir film, and brilliantly executed: mystery, intrigue, a likable hero, great antagonists, a compelling story and a great femme fatale, excellently portrayed by Mary Astor. The Maltese Falcon is one of the best examples of a noir, and is Humphrey Bogart at his finest.

Undoubtedly one of the greatest films of all time, The Maltese Falcon sees Humphrey Bogart and director John Huston working at the peak of their powers, resulting in a twisty and unpredictable thriller who's depth is just as great as its iconic lead character.

#noirvember
Archer & Spade PI quickly becomes Sam Spade PI after the duo take a case presented by a dame in distress. Sam wants to know why; he had his dirty dealings with his former partner's wife, and is even questioned by the local PD. He uses his intuition and know-how to get more information from the woman who hired them. He learns the case she initially presented is far bigger and involves a hundreds-year-old-treasure. Spade wants to make his own money, dealing with a homosexual couple of treasure-hunters while trying to stay alive. This is the epitome of what you envision for an old-school detective film.

Oh Bogart, have you ever let me down? If so, it wouldn't be here. Casablanca wins by some degree as a greater film, with this is the finer performance by Humphrey. Thrilling film noir wonderfully directed and acted. Watch it a dark night with a big bowl of popcorn next to you and a dry martini in your hand.
Maybe the most regarded noir film ever made.
They say no one's perfect. But I know a few movies that are and this is one of them. Bogart is the best of the best. 10+/10

Have you ever heard your grandparents talk like some of these movie stars from the '30's and '40's? Probably not. And not in some of the newer films either. The method school of acting changed the face of cinema.
Looking back, The Maltese falcon seems so derivative, only because so many movies since are derivative of this film. If there were a hall of fame for movie stars, Bogart would assuredly be among the first inductees, yet his acting is so heavy handed and distraught that if he were a comedian today he could star in a remake of any Jim Carey movie. Sydney Greenstreet's bizarre elocution of the English language is equally comical and Peter Lorre would seem menacing only if he had Boris Karloff along side him. And speaking of a weird butchering of English, Mary Astor's always almost-on-the-verge of fainting Brigid is pretty funny too. The script is peppered with what are nowadays cliches but must have seemed very hackneyed when the film was first released.
I'm not saying that The Maltese Falcon is a horrible film, and would have watched it even if it wasn't a requirement of a film studies class. But it isn't a great film and of course everyone is sold on the movie star constellation developed by Hollywood which, like the real universe, seems to expand further and further with each generation.

Dashiell Hammett's legendary story receives a faithful Hollywood adaptation. Like its hardboiled source material, "The Maltese Falcon" is a rabbit hole of a tale with a colorful cast of characters and some killer atmosphere.
I can't get into these detective flicks. Chaotic plots, shallow character development, lots of bad fake dying, and romances that don't make any sense.
The Maltese Falcon is one of the most gripping, complex, and luminously cast film noirs, while delivering one of Mr. Bogart's best performances.

The Maltese FalconÂ is among the most important and influential movies to emerge from the Hollywood system - as significant in some ways as its contemporary,Â Citizen Kane. In addition to providing the cinema with a new kind of private investigator (move over, Nick and Nora Charles),Â The Maltese FalconÂ supplied an entirely new style by which to tell these kinds of stories: film noir. It was the directorial birthplace of John Huston, who would become one of the dozen-or-so most revered American-born filmmakers, as well as the picture that transformed Humphrey Bogart from a B-level supporting villain to an A-level leading man. At the same time, it tells a twisty, compelling story that holds up reasonably well more than 65 years after being committed to film.

Great film-noir its very exciting
 it holds up so well after all these years so give it a watch!
Dark and mysterious with a great central performance from Humphrey Bogart. Full review later.
The Maltese Falcon is a highly enjoyable film due to it's old fashioned suspense and Humphrey Bogart is in great touch

I've never been a big fan of noir cinema, and The Maltese Falcon was another underwhelming affair from that genre for me.  While I enjoyed the performances for the most part and the interchanges between the characters, the story was just flat out uninteresting and dull for me.  I felt that while the story progressed, the characters remained the same with thin development.  Needless to say, The Maltese Falcon is recommendable to fans of noir films like Chinatown, Blade Runner etc, but for anyone expecting an intense, engaging story with deep characters, look further.

It's like any other masterfully-done film noir to consist intelligence expressed through its own language of a solid script that brings out the solidness of a nice performance, and the talented Bogart is the main attraction by going through all of the qualities and the usual points of a film noir to be an entertainment, even though there's sometimes forms of convolute within the spoken words. (A-)

This is definitive Gum Shoe stuff. It is one of the most famous examples of film noir. An attractive woman walks into the office of a San Franciso detective looking for her lost sister, and soon we are in a crime drama centered around a historical artifact of great value.

The story is good and its smart. Its the kind of movie you might have to watch two or three times to follow all the twists of the plot. The only complaint I have is a personal one, I dont really like any of the characters. They are interesting to watch, but they are all grimy or outright evil.

A great study in noir film-making classics. Bogart is wonderful as a fast talking and debonaire, sharp, and bad ass p.i. Good characters all around. The film is intense and moves fast and is a big mystery up until the very end.
Great directorial debut from John Huston as Humphrey Bogart finally hits megastardom, surrounded by an impeccable cast and great script. Essential viewing for any serious cinephile.

Great film. Good performance by Bogart -- actually, good performances all around -- along with great direction and lighting, as well as the music. Bogart really fits the detective role here, with an ending that really is hard-hitting. Might grow on me if I see it again -- between a 4 and a 4.5 for me.
